Normal wear and tear: NOT deductible from deposit. Damage beyond normal use: deductible. Collect receipts for any repairs you pay for - can offset against deposit disputes.

step5.title: Move-Out and Deposit Return
step5.description: Before moving out: clean thoroughly, minor repairs, settle all utilities. Move-out inspection: landlord checks apartment, compare to move-in condition. Take photos again. Deposit return: 7-30 days typical (check contract). Landlord deducts damages: must provide receipts/invoices. Dispute: request itemized list, negotiate, small claims court (last resort). Bank transfer return = safest.

security-deposits.doc1: Rental contract with deposit terms clearly stated
security-deposits.doc2: Deposit payment receipt (bank transfer confirmation or written receipt)
security-deposits.doc3: Move-in condition documentation (photos, videos, signed inventory)
security-deposits.doc4: Move-out condition documentation and utility bills settlement
security-deposits.costs: Deposit is returnable - not a cost unless wrongfully withheld or legitimate damages.
security-deposits.tip1: Take VIDEO walkthrough at move-in with audio timestamp (say date out loud). More convincing than photos. Open/close every door, cupboard, appliance. Turn on all lights, taps, heating. 10 minutes = deposit protection.
security-deposits.tip2: Email photos to landlord immediately after move-in. Their receipt = acknowledged condition. If dispute later, you have proof they saw and accepted initial state documentation.
security-deposits.tip3: Polish tenancy law: deposit disputes go to small claims court (do 20,000 PLN). Filing fee ~300 PLN. Process ~6 months. Often settles before court. Don't let landlord steal deposit - you have rights!
security-deposits.faq1Q: How much is a typical security deposit?
security-deposits.faq1A: 1-2 months rent is standard. For 3,000 PLN/month rent, expect 3,000-6,000 PLN deposit. Higher deposits (3+ months) unusual and negotiable. Budget for first month + deposit when moving in.
security-deposits.faq2Q: When do I get my deposit back?
security-deposits.faq2A: After moving out and final inspection. Timeline: 7-30 days typical, though legally can take longer. Check contract for specific terms. Should be bank transfer. If not returned within reasonable time (30-60 days), follow up in writing.
security-deposits.faq3Q: Can landlord keep deposit for normal wear and tear?
security-deposits.faq3A: No. Normal wear and tear (faded paint, minor scratches from regular use) is NOT deductible. Only damage beyond normal use. Landlord must prove damage with receipts/invoices. Many landlords don't know law - push back if unreasonable.
security-deposits.faq4Q: What if landlord refuses to return deposit unfairly?
security-deposits.faq4A: 1) Request itemized deduction list in writing 2) Negotiate/dispute unreasonable items 3) Threaten small claims court 4) File claim if necessary (court filing ~300 PLN). Many landlords return after threat of court. Keep all documentation.

rental-contracts.overview: Rental contracts (umowa najmu) are legal agreements between landlord (wynajmujący) and tenant (najemca). Essential document for housing rights, meldunek, legal protection. Two types: fixed-term (określony) or indefinite (nieokreślony). Must include: parties, property address, rent amount, payment terms, duration, notice period. Standard contracts protect both parties. Can be in Polish only - get translation. Register long contracts (10+ years) with notary. Breach consequences: eviction possible but requires court order (months process).
rental-contracts.req2: PESEL number (or temporary status for contract registration)
rental-contracts.req3: First month's rent and security deposit ready
rental-contracts.req4: Understanding of contract terms (get translation if needed)

step1.title: Review Contract Terms
step1.description: Essential clauses: rent amount (czynsz), payment date, contract duration, notice period (wypowiedzenie), deposit amount/conditions, maintenance responsibility, subletting rules. Fixed-term: specific end date, harder to terminate early. Indefinite: rolling contract, 3-month notice typical. Red flags: no deposit return terms, immediate eviction clauses (illegal), unlimited landlord access.

step2.title: Get Translation and Legal Review
step2.description: Contract usually in Polish only. Get Polish-speaking friend or translator to review. Professional translation: 100-200 PLN, worth it for legal clarity. Check: utilities included or separate? Who pays property tax? Renovation allowed? Pets allowed? Guests allowed? Critical: notice period (how much advance to terminate). Standard: 3 months for indefinite, fixed-term requires mutual agreement to end early.

step3.title: Negotiate Unfavorable Terms
step3.description: Negotiable: rent amount, contract length, deposit amount, renewal terms, furnished items included, pet policies. Non-negotiable basics: property address, parties' identities. Request changes in writing. Landlord refuses: decide if acceptable or find different apartment. NEVER sign without understanding fully - legally binding!

step4.title: Sign and Get Your Copy
step4.description: Both parties sign (landlord + tenant). Each gets original copy. Witnesses not required but recommended. Notary not required (unless 10+ years). Date contract clearly. Your copy essential for: meldunek registration, proof of residency, legal disputes. Keep safely. Photograph/scan as backup.

step5.title: Register for Meldunek
step5.description: Within 30 days of moving: register address (meldunek). Need landlord consent form + rental contract. Landlord refuses meldunek: illegal but common (tax avoidance). No meldunek: technically illegal for you, but many survive without. Contract = proof of residency for bank accounts, permits. If contract ends: notify Urząd Miasta within 30 days.

rental-contracts.doc2: Landlord's ID copy and property ownership proof
rental-contracts.doc3: Deposit payment receipt and first rent payment receipt
rental-contracts.costs: Contract preparation usually free (landlord provides template). Optional legal review costs.
rental-contracts.tip1: Insist on written contract - never rent with verbal agreement only! Verbal agreements legal but impossible to prove terms. No contract = no meldunek, no legal protection, easy to exploit you.
rental-contracts.tip2: Notice period is CRUCIAL - check carefully! Standard 3 months for indefinite contracts. Fixed-term: often no early termination allowed without penalty. Plan accordingly - breaking contract early = potential deposit loss.
rental-contracts.tip3: Landlord required to register rental income and pay tax. Many don't (tax evasion). They may refuse meldunek to hide income. This is THEIR problem, not yours. You can insist on contract + meldunek or report to tax office.
rental-contracts.faq1Q: Do I need a written rental contract?
rental-contracts.faq1A: Not legally required, but STRONGLY recommended. Written contract = proof of terms, legal protection, needed for meldunek, evidence in disputes. Verbal agreements legal but unenforceable in practice. Always insist on written.
rental-contracts.faq2Q: What if contract is only in Polish?
rental-contracts.faq2A: Common situation. Get Polish-speaking friend to translate and explain terms. Professional translation: 100-200 PLN. Key sections: rent amount, payment terms, duration, notice period, deposit return, maintenance responsibility. Don't sign blind!
rental-contracts.faq3Q: Can I terminate rental contract early?
rental-contracts.faq3A: Depends on contract type. Indefinite: yes, with notice period (typically 3 months). Fixed-term: difficult, requires landlord agreement or penalty. Some contracts have early termination clause. Breaking without agreement: lose deposit, potential legal liability for remaining rent.
rental-contracts.faq4Q: What if landlord refuses to give written contract?
rental-contracts.faq4A: Red flag - likely tax evasion. You have no legal protection without contract. Cannot register meldunek. Difficult to prove tenancy. Find different apartment. If already moved in: insist on contract or threaten to report to tax office (Urząd Skarbowy).
